text.tspan: By default, the "Select" tool is active. It allows to perform many edit actions in the schematic and thus it's probably the most important tool in the schematic editor.
With this tool, the user can...
- select single schematic objects by clicking on them with the left mouse button.
- select multiple schematic objects either by drawing a selection rect or by clicking on them with the left mouse button while the "Ctrl" key is pressed.
- modify all selected objects by triggering an edit action like move, rotate or mirror (from various toolbars, menus and keyboard shortcuts).
- click on the right mouse button to open a context menu of the schematic object(s) under the cursor (if there are any objects).
- click on the right mouse button to switch back to the last active tool (only if there are no schematic objects under the cursor and thus no context menu is required).
To draw wires, add netlabels, add components and so on, the user needs to switch to the corresponding tool. While these tools are active, modifications on already
existing schematic objects are typically not possible (for example moving/rotating/mirroring symbols). If a tool (except "Select") is in some kind of an "idle state",
the tool can be leaved with the "abort" action (shortcut "Esc") or with a click on the right mouse button (only if there are no schematic objects under the cursor and
thus no context menu is required). After leaving a tool, the schematic editor will always switch back to the "Select" tool.
This (very incomplete) state diagram shows the concept a little bit more detailed:

g.text: (Switch back to the last active tool)

text.tspan: Note about the right mouse button click:
Depending on the current state of the active tool, the right mouse button click has a very special role to increase the efficienty when drawing schematics.
In the "idle state" of the currently active tool, the right mouse button can be clicked to switch between that tool and the "Select" tool.
Example workflow: Draw wire segment -> right click -> move a symbol -> right click -> draw next wire segment -> right click -> move a wire segment -> ...
